awd_titl_txt: Bayesian Estimation of Restricted Latent Class Models for Ordinal and Nominal Response Data
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will advance statistical models and machine learning algorithms used to describe the structure underlying human response data. Decision makers and researchers in industry and academia collect and use large-scale datasets to understand human behavior. Current methods extract profiles underlying response data where the latent structure is known. However, the latent structure is rarely known, so existing methods are appropriate in only a few narrowly defined cases. The project will develop exploratory methods for identifying common patterns and profiles when the latent structure is unknown. The research will have broad implications in healthy populations and in clinical populations, particularly in providing decision makers with fine-grained information to accelerate human development and improve quality of life. The methods to be developed will be applied to data involving individual differences in cognitive performance, psychological factors that influence college student academic behavior, and patient health outcomes. Graduate students will be involved in the conduct of the research. Publicly available software will be developed to provide researchers and decision makers with cutting-edge tools.

This research project will develop and apply statistical models that will enable precise, powerful modeling and testing of hypotheses about systematic patterns in human response data. Restricted latent class models (RLCMs) will be investigated for a broad range of human response data, including ordinal ratings, rankings, and nominal choices. Methods for estimating the latent structure for general RLCMs for ordinal and nominal response data will be developed. Bayesian methods will be used to improve upon existing models by offering a flexible framework that explores the underlying structure. Project innovations will include establishing new identifiability theory and investigating ordinal specifications in the latent structure. Insights gained from this research could lead to significant developments in the underlying statistical theory for estimation of latent structure models. Advances in this theory will have implications for a broad spectrum of applications beyond education and psychology, including other social science disciplines and machine learning applications that cluster multivariate nominal data according to underlying features. Researchers will be provided with tools to relate the latent structure to other criteria, such as academic success, effective decision-making, and health outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Developing statistical methodology that supports personalized interventions in education, psychology, and health remains an important objective. The primary aim of this project was to create new statistical methods for applications to settings such as classifying student performance to provide teachers and families with actionable information or diagnosing patient mental health to evaluate treatments or inform interventions. In particular, the developed methods provide researchers with insight for understanding the efficacy of personalized interventions. The new procedures are designed to process large datasets consisting of students' answers to academic questions or patients ratings on symptom checklist. Decision-makers often have contextual information about respondents and another important goal of our project was to create infrastructure for understanding how student and patient characteristics relates to their latent classifications. Accordingly, new computational algorithms were formulated and tested to ensure accuracy and scalability for applied researchers. We disseminated the results from our project by publishing articles in peer reviewed journals, presenting findings at national and international conferences, and depositing our computer code so other researchers can utilize our discoveries. In addition to our scientific advancements, we contributed to human capital development by supporting and mentoring a team of students who developed skills research skills (e.g., theoretical statistics, Bayesian methods, and computational algorithms) and recieved professional development to meet the demands of the modern labor market.  


Last Modified: 08/11/2024
Modified by: Steven A Culpepper
